title: 346-C
statement: C. Number Transformation IItime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutYou are given a sequence of positive integersx1,x2, ...,xnand two non-negative integersaandb. Your task is to transformaintob. To do that, you can perform the following moves:subtract 1 from the currenta;subtractamodxi(1 ≤i≤n)from the currenta.Operationamodximeans taking the remainder after division of numberaby numberxi.Now you want to know the minimum number of moves needed to transformaintob.InputThe first line contains a single integern(1 ≤n≤ 105). The second line containsnspace-separated integersx1,x2, ...,xn(2 ≤xi≤ 109). The third line contains two integersaandb(0  ≤b≤a≤ 109,a-b≤ 106).OutputPrint a single integer — the required minimum number of moves needed to transform numberainto numberb.ExamplesInput33 4 530 17Output6Input35 6 71000 200Output206

processed.result:
You are given a sequence of positive integers $x_1, x_2, ..., x_n$ and two non-negative integers $a$ and $b$. Your task is to transform $a$ into $b$ using the following operations:

1. Subtract 1 from the current value of $a$.
2. Subtract $a \mod x_i$ (the remainder when $a$ is divided by $x_i$) from the current value of $a$. Here, $1 \le i \le n$.

Find the minimum number of operations needed to transform $a$ into $b$.

You have a starting number and a target number. You can repeatedly subtract 1 from the starting number or subtract the remainder of the starting number divided by a given list of numbers from the starting number. What is the fewest times you need to perform these operations to reach the target number?
